t: Micah 1
The*p word of the Lord*s that came to Micah of Moresheth during the reigns of Jotham, Ahaz and Hezekiah, kings of Judah—the vision he saw concerning Samaria and Jerusalem.
Hear,*pn you peoples, all of you, listen,*ld earth and all who live in it, that*ln the Sovereign Lord*s may bear witness against you, the*ld Lord from his holy temple.
Judgment Against Samaria and Jerusalem
Look!*pn The Lord*s is coming from his dwelling place; he*ld comes down and treads on the heights of the earth.
The*ln mountains melt beneath him and*ld the valleys split apart, like*ln wax before the fire, like*ld water rushing down a slope.

All*ln this is because of Jacob’s transgression, because*ld of the sins of the people of Israel. What*ln is Jacob’s transgression? Is*ld it not Samaria? What*ln is Judah’s high place? Is*ld it not Jerusalem?
“Therefore*pn I will make Samaria a heap of rubble, a*ld place for planting vineyards. I*ln will pour her stones into the valley and*ld lay bare her foundations.

All*ln her idols will be broken to pieces; all*ld her temple gifts will be burned with fire; I*ld will destroy all her images. Since*ln she gathered her gifts from the wages of prostitutes, as*ld the wages of prostitutes they will again be used.”
Weeping and Mourning
Because*pn of this I will weep and wail; I*ld will go about barefoot and naked. I*ln will howl like a jackal and*ld moan like an owl.
For*ln Samaria’s plague is incurable; it*ld has spread to Judah. It*ln has reached the very gate of my people, even*ld to Jerusalem itself.
Tell*ln it not in Gath; weep*ld not at all. In*ln Beth Ophrah roll*ld in the dust.
Pass*ln by naked and in shame, you*ld who live in Shaphir. Those*ln who live in Zaanan will*ld not come out. Beth*ln Ezel is in mourning; it*ld no longer protects you.
Those*ln who live in Maroth writhe in pain, waiting*ld for relief, because*ln disaster has come from the Lord,*s even*ld to the gate of Jerusalem.
You*ln who live in Lachish, harness*ld fast horses to the chariot. You*ln are where the sin of Daughter Zion began, for*ld the transgressions of Israel were found in you.
Therefore*ln you will give parting gifts to*ld Moresheth Gath. The*ln town of Akzib will prove deceptive to*ld the kings of Israel.
I*ln will bring a conqueror against you who*ld live in Mareshah. The*ln nobles of Israel will*ld flee to Adullam.
Shave*ln your head in mourning for*ld the children in whom you delight; make*ln yourself as bald as the vulture, for*ld they will go from you into exile.
Micah 2
Human Plans and God’s Plans
Woe*pn to those who plan iniquity, to*ld those who plot evil on their beds! At*ln morning’s light they carry it out because*ld it is in their power to do it.
They*ln covet fields and seize them, and*ld houses, and take them. They*ln defraud people of their homes, they*ld rob them of their inheritance.
Therefore,*p the Lord*s says: “I*pn am planning disaster against this people, from*ld which you cannot save yourselves. You*ln will no longer walk proudly, for*ld it will be a time of calamity.

In*ln that day people will ridicule you; they*ld will taunt you with this mournful song: ‘We*ln are utterly ruined; my*ld people’s possession is divided up. He*ln takes it from me! He*ld assigns our fields to traitors.’ ”
Therefore*pn you will have no one in the assembly of the Lord*s to*ld divide the land by lot.
False Prophets
“Do*pn not prophesy,” their prophets say. “Do*ld not prophesy about these things; disgrace*ld will not overtake us.”
You*ln descendants of Jacob, should it be said, “Does*ld the Lord*s become impatient? Does*ld he do such things?” “Do*pn not my words do good to*ld the one whose ways are upright?
Lately*ln my people have risen up like*ld an enemy. You*ln strip off the rich robe from*ld those who pass by without a care, like*ld men returning from battle.
You*ln drive the women of my people from*ld their pleasant homes. You*ln take away my blessing from*ld their children forever.
Get*ln up, go away! For*ld this is not your resting place, because*ln it is defiled, it*ld is ruined, beyond all remedy.
If*ln a liar and deceiver comes and says, ‘I*ld will prophesy for you plenty of wine and beer,’ that*ld would be just the prophet for this people!
Deliverance Promised

“I*pn will surely gather all of you, Jacob; I*ld will surely bring together the remnant of Israel. I*ln will bring them together like sheep in a pen, like*ld a flock in its pasture; the*ld place will throng with people.
The*ln One who breaks open the way will go up before them; they*ld will break through the gate and go out. Their*ln King will pass through before them, the*ld Lord*s at their head.”
Micah 3
Leaders and Prophets Rebuked
Then*p I said, “Listen,*pn you leaders of Jacob, you*ld rulers of Israel. Should*ln you not embrace justice,
you*ld who hate good and love evil; who*ln tear the skin from my people and*ld the flesh from their bones;
who*ln eat my people’s flesh, strip*ld off their skin and*ld break their bones in pieces; who*ln chop them up like meat for the pan, like*ld flesh for the pot?”
Then*pn they will cry out to the Lord,*s but*ld he will not answer them. At*ln that time he will hide his face from them because*ld of the evil they have done.

This*p is what the Lord*s says: “As*pn for the prophets who*ld lead my people astray, they*ln proclaim ‘peace’ if*ld they have something to eat, but*ln prepare to wage war against anyone who*ld refuses to feed them.
Therefore*ln night will come over you, without visions, and*ld darkness, without divination. The*ln sun will set for the prophets, and*ld the day will go dark for them.
The*ln seers will be ashamed and*ld the diviners disgraced. They*ln will all cover their faces because*ld there is no answer from God.”
But*ln as for me, I am filled with power, with*ld the Spirit of the Lord,*s and*ld with justice and might, to*ln declare to Jacob his transgression, to*ld Israel his sin.
Hear*pn this, you leaders of Jacob, you*ld rulers of Israel, who*ln despise justice and*ld distort all that is right;
who*ln build Zion with bloodshed, and*ld Jerusalem with wickedness.

Her*ln leaders judge for a bribe, her*ld priests teach for a price, and*ld her prophets tell fortunes for money. Yet*ln they look for the Lord’s*s support and say, “Is*ld not the Lord*s among us? No*ld disaster will come upon us.”
Therefore*ln because of you, Zion*ld will be plowed like a field, Jerusalem*ln will become a heap of rubble, the*ld temple hill a mound overgrown with thickets.
Micah 4
The Mountain of the Lord
In*p the last days the*pn mountain of the Lord’s*s temple will be established as*ld the highest of the mountains; it*ln will be exalted above the hills, and*ld peoples will stream to it.

Many*p nations will come and say, “Come,*pn let us go up to the mountain of the Lord,*s to*ld the temple of the God of Jacob. He*ln will teach us his ways, so*ld that we may walk in his paths.” The*ln law will go out from Zion, the*ld word of the Lord*s from Jerusalem.

He*ln will judge between many peoples and*ld will settle disputes for strong nations far and wide. They*ln will beat their swords into plowshares and*ld their spears into pruning hooks. Nation*ln will not take up sword against nation, nor*ld will they train for war anymore.
Everyone*ln will sit under their own vine and*ld under their own fig tree, and*ln no one will make them afraid, for*ld the Lord*s Almighty has spoken.
All*ln the nations may walk in*ld the name of their gods, but*ln we will walk in the name of the Lord*s our*ld God for ever and ever.
The Lord’s Plan
“In*pn that day,” declares the Lord,*s “I*ld will gather the lame; I*ln will assemble the exiles and*ld those I have brought to grief.
I*ln will make the lame my remnant, those*ld driven away a strong nation. The*ln Lord*s will rule over them in Mount Zion from*ld that day and forever.
As*ln for you, watchtower of the flock, stronghold*ld of Daughter Zion, the*ln former dominion will be restored to you; kingship*ld will come to Daughter Jerusalem.”
Why*pn do you now cry aloud— have*ld you no king? Has*ln your ruler perished, that*ld pain seizes you like that of a woman in labor?

Writhe*ln in agony, Daughter Zion, like*ld a woman in labor, for*ln now you must leave the city to*ld camp in the open field. You*ln will go to Babylon; there*ld you will be rescued. There*ln the Lord*s will redeem you out*ld of the hand of your enemies.
But*pn now many nations are*ld gathered against you. They*ln say, “Let her be defiled, let*ld our eyes gloat over Zion!”
But*ln they do not know the*ld thoughts of the Lord;*s they*ln do not understand his plan, that*ld he has gathered them like sheaves to the threshing floor.

“Rise*ln and thresh, Daughter Zion, for*ld I will give you horns of iron; I*ln will give you hooves of bronze, and*ld you will break to pieces many nations.” You*ln will devote their ill-gotten gains to the Lord,*s their*ld wealth to the Lord of all the earth.
Micah 5
A Promised Ruler From Bethlehem
Marshal*pn your troops now, city of troops, for*ld a siege is laid against us. They*ln will strike Israel’s ruler on*ld the cheek with a rod.

“But*pn you, Bethlehem Ephrathah, though*ld you are small among the clans of Judah, out*ln of you will come for me one*ld who will be ruler over Israel, whose*ln origins are from of old, from*ld ancient times.”
Therefore*pn Israel will be abandoned until*ld the time when she who is in labor bears a son, and*ln the rest of his brothers return to*ld join the Israelites.

He*pn will stand and shepherd his flock in*ld the strength of the Lord,*s in*ld the majesty of the name of the Lord*s his God. And*ln they will live securely, for then his greatness will*ld reach to the ends of the earth.
And*pn he will be our peace when*ld the Assyrians invade our land and*ld march through our fortresses. We*ln will raise against them seven shepherds, even*ld eight commanders,
who*ln will rule the land of Assyria with the sword, the*ld land of Nimrod with drawn sword. He*ln will deliver us from the Assyrians when*ld they invade our land and*ld march across our borders.
The*pn remnant of Jacob will be in*ld the midst of many peoples like*ln dew from the Lord,*s like*ld showers on the grass, which*ln do not wait for anyone or*ld depend on man.

The*ln remnant of Jacob will be among the nations, in*ld the midst of many peoples, like*ln a lion among the beasts of the forest, like*ld a young lion among flocks of sheep, which*ln mauls and mangles as it goes, and*ld no one can rescue.
Your*ln hand will be lifted up in triumph over your enemies, and*ld all your foes will be destroyed.
“In*p that day,” declares the Lord,*s “I*pn will destroy your horses from among you and*ld demolish your chariots.
I*ln will destroy the cities of your land and*ld tear down all your strongholds.
I*ln will destroy your witchcraft and*ld you will no longer cast spells.
I*ln will destroy your idols and*ld your sacred stones from among you; you*ln will no longer bow down to*ld the work of your hands.
I*ln will uproot from among you your Asherah poles when*ld I demolish your cities.
I*ln will take vengeance in anger and wrath on*ld the nations that have not obeyed me.”
Micah 6
The Lord’s Case Against Israel
Listen*p to what the Lord*s says: “Stand*pn up, plead my case before the mountains; let*ld the hills hear what you have to say.
“Hear,*pn you mountains, the Lord’s*s accusation; listen,*ld you everlasting foundations of the earth. For*ln the Lord*s has a case against his people; he*ld is lodging a charge against Israel.
“My*pn people, what have I done to you? How*ld have I burdened you? Answer me.
I*ln brought you up out of Egypt and*ld redeemed you from the land of slavery. I*ln sent Moses to lead you, also*ld Aaron and Miriam.

My*ln people, remember what*ld Balak king of Moab plotted and*ld what Balaam son of Beor answered. Remember*ln your journey from Shittim to Gilgal, that*ld you may know the righteous acts of the Lord.”*s
With*pn what shall I come before the Lord*s and*ld bow down before the exalted God? Shall*ln I come before him with burnt offerings, with*ld calves a year old?
Will*ln the Lord*s be pleased with thousands of rams, with*ld ten thousand rivers of olive oil? Shall*ln I offer my firstborn for my transgression, the*ld fruit of my body for the sin of my soul?
He*ln has shown you, O mortal, what is good. And*ld what does the Lord*s require of you? To*ln act justly and to love mercy and*ld to walk humbly with your God.
Israel’s Guilt and Punishment
Listen!*pn The Lord*s is calling to the city— and*ld to fear your name is wisdom— “Heed*ld the rod and the One who appointed it.
Am*ln I still to forget your ill-gotten treasures, you wicked house, and*ld the short ephah, which is accursed?
Shall*ln I acquit someone with dishonest scales, with*ld a bag of false weights?
Your*ln rich people are violent; your*ld inhabitants are liars and*ld their tongues speak deceitfully.
Therefore,*ln I have begun to destroy you, to*ld ruin you because of your sins.
You*ln will eat but not be satisfied; your*ld stomach will still be empty. You*ln will store up but save nothing, because*ld what you save I will give to the sword.
You*ln will plant but not harvest; you*ld will press olives but not use the oil, you*ld will crush grapes but not drink the wine.

You*ln have observed the statutes of Omri and*ld all the practices of Ahab’s house; you*ld have followed their traditions. Therefore*ln I will give you over to ruin and*ld your people to derision; you*ld will bear the scorn of the nations.”
Micah 7
Israel’s Misery
What*pn misery is mine! I*ln am like one who gathers summer fruit at*ld the gleaning of the vineyard; there*ln is no cluster of grapes to eat, none*ld of the early figs that I crave.
The*ln faithful have been swept from the land; not*ld one upright person remains. Everyone*ln lies in wait to shed blood; they*ld hunt each other with nets.
Both*ln hands are skilled in doing evil; the*ld ruler demands gifts, the*ln judge accepts bribes, the*ld powerful dictate what they desire— they*ld all conspire together.
The*ln best of them is like a brier, the*ld most upright worse than a thorn hedge. The*ln day God visits you has come, the*ld day your watchmen sound the alarm. Now*ld is the time of your confusion.
Do*ln not trust a neighbor; put*ld no confidence in a friend. Even*ln with the woman who lies in your embrace guard*ld the words of your lips.
For*ln a son dishonors his father, a*ld daughter rises up against her mother, a*ln daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law— a*ld man’s enemies are the members of his own household.
But*pn as for me, I watch in hope for the Lord,*s I*ld wait for God my Savior; my*ld God will hear me.
Israel Will Rise
Do*pn not gloat over me, my enemy! Though*ld I have fallen, I will rise. Though*ln I sit in darkness, the*ld Lord*s will be my light.
Because*ln I have sinned against him, I*ld will bear the Lord’s*s wrath, until*ln he pleads my case and*ld upholds my cause. He*ln will bring me out into the light; I*ld will see his righteousness.

Then*ln my enemy will see it and*ld will be covered with shame, she*ln who said to me, “Where*ld is the Lord*s your God?” My*ln eyes will see her downfall; even*ld now she will be trampled underfoot like*ld mire in the streets.
The*pn day for building your walls will come, the*ld day for extending your boundaries.
In*ln that day people will come to you from*ld Assyria and the cities of Egypt, even*ln from Egypt to the Euphrates and*ld from sea to sea and*ld from mountain to mountain.
The*ln earth will become desolate because of its inhabitants, as*ld the result of their deeds.
Prayer and Praise

Shepherd*pn your people with your staff, the*ld flock of your inheritance, which*ln lives by itself in a forest, in*ld fertile pasturelands. Let*ln them feed in Bashan and Gilead as*ld in days long ago.
“As*pn in the days when you came out of Egypt, I*ld will show them my wonders.”
Nations*pn will see and be ashamed, deprived*ld of all their power. They*ln will put their hands over their mouths and*ld their ears will become deaf.

They*ln will lick dust like a snake, like*ld creatures that crawl on the ground. They*ln will come trembling out of their dens; they*ld will turn in fear to the Lord*s our God and*ld will be afraid of you.
Who*ln is a God like you, who*ld pardons sin and forgives the transgression of*ld the remnant of his inheritance? You*ln do not stay angry forever but*ld delight to show mercy.
You*ln will again have compassion on us; you*ld will tread our sins underfoot and*ld hurl all our iniquities into the depths of the sea.
You*ln will be faithful to Jacob, and*ld show love to Abraham, as*ln you pledged on oath to our ancestors in*ld days long ago.
